urn:contentItem:3XS2-0CC0-009B-G35D-00000-00Tech Stocks Drive Nasdaq to New High; SBC Communications Becomes Dow's First-Ever Baby Bell; Hershey's has High-Tech Halloween Horror1999-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:43ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30 pm ETBusinessSHOW99102900V19Tech Stocks Drive Nasdaq to New High; SBC Communications Becomes Dow's First-Ever Baby Bell; Hershey's has High-Tech Halloween HorrorWillow Bay, Stuart Varney, Greg Clarkin, Bill Dorman, Allan Dodds Frank, Kelli Arena, Fred Katayama, Bruce Francis, Peter Viles, Casey Wian

October proved that its bad reputation is based more on superstition than real performance, as it was a dazzling day for technology and a record- setting day for the Nasdaq composite, which has now more than doubled over the past year, closing at a record high of 2966. The Texas-based telecom SBC Communications is the nation's biggest Baby Bell, and it's about to become the first ever to join the venerable Dow 30. But is now the time to buy or to sell this new blue chip. Hershey found its leading-edge technology failed to deliver the goods with a supply nightmare just in time for Halloween -- all because the country's top candy maker didn't get the gremlins out of its new computer system.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, ANCHOR: Tonight, tech stocks drive the Nasdaq to a new high, exactly 70 years after that dark day on Wall Street known as Black Tuesday.

STUART VARNEY, ANCHOR: "The Bottom Line" on a brand-new blue chip, SBC Communications, about to become the Dow's first ever Baby Bell.

BAY: Halloween horror for the nation's number-one candy maker. Hershey's high-tech nightmare.

VARNEY: Cursed by the Blair Witch? Not Burkittsville, Maryland. Cashing in on its new-found fame.

BAY: And a "Playboy" centerfold locked in a billion-dollar battle over her late husband's estate.

ANNOUNCER: This is THE MONEYLINE NEWSHOUR. Reporting tonight from New York, Stuart Varney and Willow Bay.

BAY: Good evening, and welcome to MONEYLINE.

It's the month that scares investors the most.

VARNEY: True, but once again, October proved that its bad reputation is based more on superstition than real performance. For the second day running, stocks jumped all across the board, with the Dow, Nasdaq, and the S&P all closing out the month solidly in the black.

In fact, the Nasdaq is going into November at a new record, and the S&P had its best October since way back in 1982.

Today's rally built on yesterday's huge gains, with inflation fears firmly in check.

Greg Clarkin has more from Wall Street, the scene of more than one celebration today.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Outside the New York Stock Exchange was a jam-packed tribute to the world champion Yankees. Inside, it was yet another busy day of buying with stocks taking off across the board for the second straight day on big volume.

The Dow soared as high as 168 points and ended with a 107-point gain. The Nasdaq surged to a record close, gaining more than three percent. Helping spark today's rally, more tame economic news, this time from the housing market. Bonds were sharply higher, sending long-term yields tumbling, all good news for Wall Street.

LINDA DUESSEL, FEDERATED EQUITY INCOME FUND: The last two days have been extremely healthy. Obviously a big break out to the upside. And thanks in large part to the behavior of the bond market, which I was really fearful we couldn't make an advance without the bond market doing better. And it is.

CLARKIN: The bond rally, however, did not help some financial stocks, especially American Express. After a big run-up, AmEx plunged on several analysts' downgrades. It was tech stocks that took charge after Intel's bullish comments late yesterday, Intel and Sun Microsystems among the stocks that surged.

But can it continue?

ROCKY BARBER, WILLIAM BLAIR GROWTH FUND: There's been some run- ups in major categories like technology, and I think they're warranted in the long run. But they might be a little ahead of themselves.

CLARKIN: One brand-new stock got ahead of everybody today, Akamai, which offers ways to speed up Web traffic. It more than quintupled in its debut.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

Now, clearly investors were not haunted by this history of this date. Seventy years ago today, the Dow plunged 30 points, and that followed a drop of 38 points the day before, for a two-day loss of nearly 25 percent. October 29, 1929, it became known as Black Tuesday, and the Dow closed at 230. Today's close on the Dow, 10,729 -- Stuart.

VARNEY: On a day like this, that's a very distant memory, is it not?

Greg Clarkin reporting. Thanks, Greg.

CLARKIN: Sure.

BAY: Lockheed Martin is buffeted by a profit warning that brings down one of its top executives. The aerospace company said earnings and cash flow in 2000 would come out at half that of forecasts.

And president and COO Peter Teets is paying for the shortfall with his job.

Behind the coming losses, a slump in its commercial space business and launch delays in its satellite ventures. Lockheed Martin ended down nearly three. The stock has lost nearly two-thirds of its value over the past year.

VARNEY: DaimlerChrysler is overhauling its business to put North American operations under one hood, so to speak. The streamlining is expected to give executives more autonomy on this side of the Atlantic, and it's part of a bid to recapture the innovative spirit of the old Chrysler. The auto maker has been trying to regain momentum after the North American president, Thomas Stallkamp, stepped down last month.

The plan splits operations into three units, Mercedes Benz, Chrysler, and commercial vehicles.

BAY: Turning now to the latest economic numbers, which showed a sharp slowdown last month in new home sales. That was more good news for the bond market, fueling hopes that the economy is not overheating. The 30-year bond rocketed more than a full point, with the yield down to 6.16 percent.

Patty Davis looks at what's cooling off the housing boom.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PATTY DAVIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The red-hot housing market is finally starting to loose some of its sizzle. Buckling under the weight of higher interest rates, new home sales posted their biggest drop in more than five years in September, plummeting 12.8 percent to the lowest rate in almost two years.

BETH WHEELER RYAN, PALORMO REALTY: End of August and into September, the market was just dead. No one was even looking at property. And when interest rates go up a little bit, people just tend not to make decisions.

DAVIS: And the lack of decision-making cannot be blamed on Hurricane Floyd. Sales fell sharply on both coasts, with the steepest drops coming in the Floyd-free Midwest and West. That leaves mortgage rates. After starting the year at 6.75 percent, 30-year mortgages this week hit 8 percent.

STAN SHIPLEY, MERRILL LYNCH: The higher mortgage rates that we've witnessed over the last six months is starting to temper demand for the housing sector. New home sales and existing home sales are falling here because mortgage rates have risen 125 basis points.

DAVIS: Still, no one expects the housing market to collapse. Even with September's drop, home sales remain on pace for a fourth straight record-setting year. With incomes rising and jobs plentiful, real estate agents are already seeing signs of a pickup in business.

RYAN: October, it's been a great month, because it seems like no one did anything in September. So now in October they're making their decisions.

DAVIS: And the first week of November could be busy as well.

(on camera): Mortgage rates are tied directly to the Treasury bond market, so this week's sharp rise in bond prices and fall in interest rates will lower borrowing costs for home buyers who've waited to lock in their loans.

Patty Davis, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS, Chicago.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: Home buyers are assessing the dramatic drop in market rates this week, and so too, of course, are investors.

Joining us now from Pittsburgh, we have with us Tom Madden of Federated Investors. Tom manages some $23 billion, primarily in stock and bond funds.

Tom, welcome to MONEYLINE.

TOM MADDEN, CIO, FEDERATED INVESTORS: Good evening, Stuart.

VARNEY: Now, we have a big rally in the bond market this week, and a very strong rally in stocks in the last two days. Now, do you think that this may be the start of a new leg up for the bull market in stocks?

MADDEN: Well, I think it's a much more reasonable bet than it was at the beginning of the week, and the litmus test is the long bond. We've had a very powerful rally at the wrong end of the yield curve, and that tells me that bond rates, which have considerable influence over the level of common stocks, are moving in the right direction. So I'm encouraged.

VARNEY: Twelve thousand on the Dow by early in the new year?

MADDEN: Yes, I actually had that number before this week, so I'm hoping some of my friends on our sales force will give me a little credit. But that's what we're looking for.

VARNEY: Good luck on that one, Tom, now. Which companies are driving this truly dynamic economy? And which stocks are driving this dynamic bull market?

MADDEN: Well, I think that if you take a little bit longer look at the stock market, the two big positives that are causing the army of stocks to sort of advance are -- really have been the global recovery and the build-out of the global Internet or World Wide Web.

And if that army's advance was going to be slowed, it was going to be slowed by the guns of the central bankers. And I think in a certain sense, what the market has been fretting about is the gun, a sort of a small-bore rifle, or is it a giant cannon which is going to discharge, you know, multiple rounds?

And I think that after the statistics this week, a lot of people feel more comfortable that any actions that the U.S. Fed takes or the Euro Central Bank takes will be moderate and fewer in number. And that should allow continued leadership -- this is the key, to me -- by big tech and by major financial stocks. And you can see much increased enthusiasm in both quarters in the market this week.

VARNEY: Major high-tech stocks, that's clearly a big part of your portfolio. But Internet stocks, are you dabbling in there, in that area?

MADDEN: Well, we have been a little more cautious on the dot- coms, Stuart, and we felt that, you know, at some point in life, you have to have a real business plan and you have to have real positive cash flow from the operating cycle, and you have to have real book profits.

And I'm following the goings-on with Amazon.com very closely, because it seems to me that this is a sort of a bellwether for some of the difficulties which may continue to engage the dot-coms.

So we've really underemphasized those in our portfolio, and emphasized much more the EMCs and Ciscos and IBMs, which we think will be around for the duration.

VARNEY: Fair enough. Tom Madden from Federated Investors, joining us from Pittsburgh, many thanks for being with us, Tom.

MADDEN: My pleasure.

BAY: Let's find out now what MONEYLINE's other reporters are working on for the rest of tonight's show.

We'll begin with Bill Dorman -- Bill.

BILL DORMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Thanks, Willow.

Much more ahead on the troubles of Lockheed Martin. The company's stock hit a new 52-week low today. But before you start buying, there's some more news you should know.

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Bruce Francis.

The name of this IPO means "cool" in Hawaiian, but demand was red-hot for Akamai in its first day of trading. I'll tell you why investors were clamoring for shares.

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT: And I'm Peter Viles.

You know, Intel, Microsoft, and Home Depot. But do you know the other new Dow stock? Tonight, "The Bottom Line" on SBC, the Baby Bell that's becoming a blue chip -- Willow.

BAY: Thank you, Peter. Those stories ahead.

But coming up next, the timing could not be worse. Hershey, haunted by a high-tech nightmare for Halloween.

VARNEY: Ah, yes, with the holidays also about treats for one tiny town in Maryland, we'll tell you about the windfall from the Blair Witch virus, when the MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR returns.

ANNOUNCER: From CNN's New York headquarters, this is THE MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Tyco International tops tonight's "MONEYLINE Movers," down 3 7/8. And it was the most active stock on the baseball. "The New York Times" raised new questions about Tyco's accounting practices. But two analysts tell MONEYLINE there was nothing new revealed in the article, and that they still do not believe that Tyco abused accounting rules.

Network Solutions up 16 1/4, Lehman Brothers restated its new buy -- its buy rating for the Internet name registrar and raised its price target to $150 a share.

The Gap up 2 3/8. Goldman Sachs added the retailer to its recommended list. Yesterday, Robert Fisher resigned as president of Gap Stores.

BAY: In other headlines, some big management changes at the world's largest beverage company. Coca-Cola said senior VP Jack Stahl will take over responsibility for North America, Latin America, and the Minute Maid Company. Ralph Cooper will leave Minute Maid to become president of the North America group. He will report to Stall.

The changes come just over one week after Coca-Cola reported an 11 percent drop in profits.

And Levi Strauss will unzip its online stores. Due to high costs, the struggling jeans maker will stop selling merchandise on its Web sites after Christmas. Levi's clothing and accessories will now be sold on Web sites operated by J.C. Penney and Macy's.

VARNEY: Technology stocks not the only standout in today's session. Another strong sector was paper stocks. The group tore ahead on positive comments from Merrill Lynch. It restated its long- term buy ratings for International Paper and Champion International. The chief executive of International Paper spoke about his company's future at the Business Council meeting in Florida.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN DILLON, CEO, INTERNATIONAL PAPER: My expectations, as we look forward over the next two months and year, is we'll continue to see a very good market condition, and very good opportunities for International Paper.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VARNEY: And here's how the sector did today. International Paper up nearly 4 1/4, Champion International gained more than 4 1/4, Merrill Lynch also upgraded and restated its ratings on other paper stocks today. They went up, Boise Cascade gaining nearly 4 3/4, Weyerhaeuser up more than 4, Georgia Pacific gained more than 3 points.

BAY: Hershey finds its leading-edge technology fails to deliver the goods. A supply nightmare just in time for Halloween, all because the country's top candy maker didn't get the gremlins out of its new computer system.

Allan Dodds Frank has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ALLAN DODDS FRANK, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): At this candy wholesaler, Halloween will be here before some Hershey's shipments of chocolates and lollipops arrive.

Antonio Pelaez, Jr.'s Master Wholesaling Company buys more than $6 million worth of Hershey's candy a year. Despite being a guest of Hershey salesmen at the last World Series game, he's upset with the company.

ANTONIO PELAEZ, JR., PRESIDENT, ANPESIL DISTRIBUTORS: Now you can see, there's a lot of empty spots that belongs to the Hershey palette, and usually there is (INAUDIBLE) of a truckload is missing here right now, do (ph) because they cannot make the deliveries in time.

FRANK: Across the country, Hershey's customers are bedeviled by incomplete shipments, mixed-up orders, and sometimes no shipment at all. That's why Anpesil ordered more Mars and Nestle's products.

PELAEZ: At the present time, we are ahead with Mars about 10 percent, and Nestle will be almost the same thing.

FRANK: Hershey's new computerized shipping system, installed last July, is the problem, and it is still not fixed. The company estimates it will cost more than $100 million in sales for Halloween, the biggest candy day of the year.

JOHN MCMILLIN, PRUDENTIAL SECURITIES: I'm sure there's going to be a couple stores in America where a consumer's going to go in and ask for Hershey chocolate bars, and the retailer's going to say, I don't have any. And the consumer's going to say, Trick or treat. I mean, it's going to be -- it's going to cause some surprise. But I would argue that that will be the exception rather than the rule.

FRANK: Still, some investors have lost their taste for Hershey's stock, melting 18 percent from its share price since the beginning of the year.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

If Hershey's Halloween chill continues. the question is, will retailers switch some shelf space to competitors, or will they still stick with the nation's number one candy maker?

Willow?

BAY: Thank you, Allan. Allan Dodds Frank reporting.

VARNEY: When MONEYLINE returns, he was gracious in victory and gracious in defeat. Today, his tear-stained memorial for golf champ Payne Stewart.

BAY: It was a celebration of an extraordinary life. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: An extraordinary tribute to the life of golfer Payne Stewart today near his home in Orlando, Florida.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED SINGER (singing): Hey, God, I just lost a dear old friend.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VARNEY: Surrounded by friends from both on the links and of, Stewart's wife, Tracey, and their two children heard an outpouring of affection for the tough 42-year-old competitor who had a zest for life. Pro golfer and close friend Paul Azinger began his eulogy by adopting the golfer's trademark fashion style.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL AZINGER, FRIEND: I always felt intimidated when I was going out with Payne because I knew he was going to assess what I was wearing. I felt pressure this morning, knowing he'd be watching.

TRACEY STEWART, PAYNE STEWART'S WIFE: I thank you, Payne, for telling me every single day of our life together that you loved me. I knew it already, but it sure was good to hear you say it.

As I look back now, I realize that even after 18 years of marriage Payne was still the most beautiful man I'd ever seen, not because of the way he looked on the outside any more, but because of what was on the inside.

We love you. Let the party in Heaven begin.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VARNEY: Meanwhile, the investigation into the cause of Monday's crash suffered another setback today. Federal aviation officials recovered the jet's cockpit voice recorder but discovered it was damaged in the crash. It's been sent to a lab to see if it can still yield any clues.

BAY: From President Clinton, a new proposal to shield the privacy of medical records. Under the plan, the release of computerized records would be tightly restricted. Patient consent would be required before distribution to employers or marketing companies. The rules would not apply to older paper records. Those require congressional action to protect.

VARNEY: A decision tonight which may have far-reaching implications for the First Amendment and the entire financial advice book genre. The Beardstown Ladies investment club rocketed to fame earlier in the decade with their homespun investment wisdom and Gotham-sized returns.

The problem, you may recall, is that those returns turned out to be wildly inflated. A much-touted 23 percent investment gain turned out to be a much more modest 9.1 percent.

A California appellate court has now ruled that the book jacket blurbs, which claim readers will be able to, quote, "learn how to outperform professional money managers by 3 to 1," it's all false or misleading commercial speech and not protected by the First Amendment.

The decision could make publishers dramatically tone down the hyperbole common to promotional material.

BAY: It's said that the only thing certain in life are death and taxes. Well, come New Year's, add Y2K. In a letter to Congress, the Internal Revenue Service says it's preparing a backup system to issue tax refunds manually instead of electronically.

Turns out the IRS is experiencing, quote, "trouble spots" at a number of field offices. The problem, high-risk, antiquated computer systems. The service does say it is confident it will resolve problems by the new year but is making contingency plans anyway.

VARNEY: All right. When MONEYLINE returns, a real-life Halloween story that ends with a treat.

BAY: A town bewitched by a movie scares up the cash for Blair- crazed fans.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Finally this half hour, the $100,000 movie "Blair Witch Project" took America by storm, grossing $140 million since its summer release. It's also managed to turn the movie's location, the hamlet of Burkittsville, Maryland, into a magnet for the curious.

Kelli Arena reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KELLI ARENA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Trude Head was initially angry when strangers from all of the world invaded her tiny town. But her attitude is different now.

TRUDE HEAD, BURKITTSVILLE RESIDENT: They all were very friendly, and I guess you have to be friendly back.

ARENA: Especially if you're trying to sell Burkittsville dirt, local herbs, and other witchy items to souvenir-hungry tourists.

HEAD: It's burning the death of darkness and the birth of light. See? So actually those stick-figures are a very positive sign.

ARENA: There are no stores in this sleepy hamlet, population 200. And on a good day, Mrs. Head pulls in as much as $300.

(on camera): This graveyard is featured in the opening scenes of the film and is the most-visited site in Burkittsville. The rest of the movie was not shot here, but that doesn't seem to matter to tourists looking for a "Blair Witch" fix.

(voice-over): They make their way from the cemetery to Margaret Kennedy's art studio, where she's taken to selling T-shirts and witch postcards.

MARGARET KENNEDY, ARTIST: This has been a short course, crash course in souvenir hunters.

ARENA: And Burkittsville grandmas are selling sticks and stones on the online auction site eBay.

While residents are cashing in, the town has actually lost money, $5,000 to date on extra police patrols, brochures, and replacing stolen property.

MAYOR JOYCE BROWN, BURKITTSVILLE: We are dealing with a very tight budget, and we have less than $100,000 to work with. And this movie has certainly cost us.

ARENA: As for this Halloween, the town is bracing for as many as 1,000 visitors. But the spell could soon be broken.

HEAD: It will not last, you know. We are going to be a quiet town again.

ARENA: Kelli Arena, CNN financial news, Burkittsville, Maryland.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: You're watching THE MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR.

BAY: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: The MONEYLINE news hour continues.

Here again, Stuart Varney and Willow Bay.

BAY: In tonight's headlines, in one of it's best point gains ever, the Nasdaq powers through yet another all-time high.

But Lockheed Martin dives to a new low on -- what else? -- a very gloomy profit warning.

Also tonight, our regular Friday feature, "The Bottom Line." SBC Communications: As it enters the Dow, is it the Baby Bell to buy or sell?

VARNEY: First, our top story: the rip-roaring rally on Wall Street. The market ended the week, and the month, on a stellar note, defying the dreaded October stigma. In fact, it was a dazzling day for technology, and a record-setting day for the Nasdaq composite, which is now more than double -- repeat, more than double -- over the past year.

Fred Katayama has more on October's pleasant surprise.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Euphoria engulfed Wall Street. Spectators cheered the Yankees as investors took the Fed chairman's remarks on inflation as good for the markets.

Mutual funds and other institutional investors took it as a green light, bolting from the sidelines to go shopping for a broad array of stocks.

GREGG HYMOWTIZ, MONEY MGR. ENTRUST CAPITAL: A lot of numbers, and a lot of the speech and commentary have all been very tame. CPI, ECI, durable goods, housing stocks -- really, everything you can point to are -- is showing that you have inflation in check.

KATAYAMA: Many investors were left with that impression after Alan Greenspan hinted in a speech last night that rising bond yields seem to be keeping the economy from overheating.

Big name technology stocks led the rally on heavy volume, after Intel said it will meet orders for chips. That helped propel the NASDAQ composite to a record high of 91 points to 2966. It gained eight percent for the month.

The Dow Jones industrials rocketed 107 points for the month. The Dow rose almost four percent. An impressive feat, say market watchers, given the perception that October is a spooky month for investors, in part because of the crashes of 1929 and '87.

In the end, investors weathered earlier scares such as cautious comments from Fed officials, concerns over Y2K, earnings warnings from several high-profile companies including Dell and Union Carbide.

ROGER DEBARD, HOTCHKIS AND WILEY: We have come through the October period pretty well, but I wouldn't just assign that concern for risk in October. We still have got November and December to go for 1999.

So you are going to have a season of tax-loss selling coming up in now in November and December.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KATAYAMA: And other market watchers say for a rally to continue interest rates must come down further, and advancing stocks must thoroughly rout declining stocks?

Stuart and Willow.

VARNEY: Haven't seen that just yet, though. There you are, Fred Katayama, thank you -- Willow.

BAY: Investors welcome news that the red-hot housing market is cooling off. Sales of new homes plunged 12.8 percent last month to their lowest level in nearly two years. Economists have been predicting climbing mortgage rates would tame the housing boom and keep the economy from overheating.

The inflation-wary bond market rallied on the news. The 30-year Treasury shot up more than a full point in price, pushing the yield all the way down to 6.16 percent. That is it's lowest level in three weeks.

VARNEY: Now let's take a closer look at how today's stock market ran up so big. On the big board, for the second straight day, winners beat losers by a better than two-to-one margin.

And for the first time in weeks -- long, long time -- there were more new highs than lows.

117 stocks hit new 52-week highs; 93 fell to those lows.

Today's big boost came from the tech's. Lucent's up 1 1/4, Motorola up 3 5/8.

There were some losers. American Express, for example, down seven after Morgan Stanley said the stock was over-valued.

And Tycho fell another 3 7/8 after the company admitted to the "New York Times" that it did not clearly disclose losses from acquisitions.

BAY: And one of the day's biggest losers: Lockheed Martin. It dropped nearly three or 12 percent, with more than 14 million shares changing hands, seven times normal volume. Its quarterly profits were impressive but its outlook for the future was anything but. Lockheed warned of an earnings shortfall next year, and announced the resignation of its president.

Bill Dorman has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BILL DORMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Shares of the nation's second leading military contractor are under attack. Lockheed Martin makes everything from missiles and fighter jets, to satellites and rockets. Only Boeing gets more orders from the Pentagon.

As recently as last month, Lockheed Martin was expecting earnings-per-share next year of $2.15. Now, the company expects less than half of that.

ROBERT FRIEDMAN, S&P EQUITY GROUP: They really don't have a handle on the extent of the problems that they're facing in their core businesses. DORMAN: Aircraft orders are declining. Satellite launch failures are increasing. So are investment costs for a reusable launch vehicle to replace the space shuttle.

The company's president and chief operating officer, Peter Teets, is resigning, taking responsibility for the earning's shocker. In a written statement he said:

"The difficult times we have seen are not indicative of the company's real potential."

Investors have tired of waiting for Lockheed. So far this year, the company's stock has dropped by more than half. And analysts warn a departing president will not solve the company's troubles.

JOSEPH CAMPBELL, LEHMAN BROTHERS: There's all kinds of problems. When you have 70 percent of the market value go away, it takes a lot more than one person to do this kind of damage, so Lockheed has problems pretty much across the board.

DORMAN: Earlier this year, Lockheed's Titan IV rocket set an $800 million communication's satellite into a useless orbit, the company's fourth high profile launch failure in less than a year.

(on camera): Another challenge is the F-22 fighter jet. Once the Air Force's next generation choice, the airplane now faces certain delays, and possible death from congressional budget cuts -- Willow.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: Thanks, Bill. Bill Dorman reporting.

VARNEY: Still to come on MONEYLINE, a former playmate battles for half a billion. Anna Nicole Smith, fighting a legal battle that could make her one of the richest women in America.

BAY: But, right after the break, the tech-heavy Nasdaq shatters yet another record.

What's next? Well, we'll ask top fund manager David Alger when MONEYLINE returns.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Among today's big stock movers: Micron Technology up nearly 3 3/4. Merrill Lynch made positive comments about the memory- chip maker, saying tight supply in the D-RAM market will continue through the end of next year.

Electronic Data Systems up 4 1/2. Late yesterday, the technology services giant reported better than expected profits. Brown Brothers Harriman repeated its buy rating and said the turnaround at EDS is on schedule.

JDS Uniphase up nearly 14 1/2. BancBoston Robertson Stephens initiated coverage after it beat earnings estimates. The telecom- equipment maker said sales more than doubled. And

America Online up 2 1/2. It added to a sharp rally in late trading yesterday, after it announced a two-for-one stock split.

BAY: Technology stocks are the subject of tonight's "MONEYLINE Focus." The big names in computers and the Internet have fueled a spectacular run for the Nasdaq composite this year. It's now up more than 35 percent in 1999. That's more than double the Dow industrials' gains, and three times the S&P 500.

Joining us now, veteran tech investor, David Alger. He manages more than 12 billion dollars in assets at the company which bears his name.

David, welcome back to MONEYLINE.

DAVID ALGER, FUND MANAGER: Delighted to be here.

BAY: Let me just read you something: By the time we get to October, the economy is going to be growing more slowly, the bond market is going to have a rally, and we'll be off to the races. Sound familiar?

ALGER: Sounds very familiar to me, yes.

BAY: You said that to us in the August. What did you know then that we didn't?

ALGER: Well, you know, it's really interesting. I think its only been in the last couple of weeks that the -- it's been become apparent that the economy really is going more slowly.

I mean, the housing statistics is one thing that, you know, been very important.

But I think it's really interesting if you are look at the GDP numbers, the deflator was so low. And I think that has been a big contributor to the bond market rally, also.

BAY: When you look at the market, are we seeing just a good rally or are we seeing a change in sentiment?

ALGER: I think what we'll see is going to be a lot of volatility between now and the Fed meeting. But I think there has been a change in sentiment to the effect that a lot of people now would say that the Fed probably is not going to raise rates in November. And I think that is a big shift from two weeks ago.

BAY: What do you think?

ALGER: I don't think the Fed will raise rates. I think there's a lot of reasons why they won't. Number one, the economy is slowing, as we've said.

Number two, the Y2K problem, you, which is, you know, the Fed wants to create liquidity, and that's not the way to do it certainly. Number three, I think that the signs of inflation are really diminishing. The deflator is one. The employment cost index of course is another.

BAY: You mentioned volatility a second ago. It has become commonplace to see the Nasdaq go up or down 1 percent a day. Will we continue to see that kind of volatility? Should we just get used to it?

ALGER: I don't know. This month has been really amazing. I mean, when you think about, the month started on the Dow at 10200, and, you know, moved up to 10700, dropped to 9880 or something like that, and is now back at 10800, up 600 on the month. I mean, that's pretty amazing.

BAY: Do you still think, as you did in August, that we are going to see growth in the tech sector in the 30 percent to 50 percent, and perhaps might even accelerate?

ALGER: I think so. I think it's going to be the most exciting sector for the next five years.

BAY: Some of your top holdings -- Microsoft. Great earning's report. I think they used the word "awesome" in describing their demand. But some fund managers are suggested that this is not the momentum play that it once was. What's your reaction?

ALGER: Well, I think that they're keying off Steve Ballmer's comments that his stock is grotesquely overvalued or whatever he said. I don't happen to agree with that. I mean, clearly, if you add back in the deferred revenue, Microsoft is not going quite as quickly as it was. But I think that's a product-cycle question. And I think gross is going to reaccelerate.

BAY: We of course waiting for the findings of fact from Judge Jackson in their trial. What will a negative finding of fact do to that stock?

ALGER: I'm not sure it's going to do anything, because I think, you know, what is the remedy? If they split it up, I think the company grows faster -- or the companies grow faster. It will be more exciting stock. You know, if they fine, it, you know, there's not enough money in the world to fine Microsoft. So what can they really do to it?

BAY: We have about 20 seconds left. I'd like your take on Internet stocks. Are you putting money in them?

ALGER: Yes. We like it a lot. I think the numbers that are going to be reported for the fourth quarter -- not the third quarter, but the fourth quarter -- are just going to be spectacular. I think Amazon might do $750 million in business in the fourth quarter.

BAY: So you're not worried about any of these e-commerce stocks?

ALGER: Not at all. BAY: We hear so much about them plowing hundreds of millions of dollars into marketing costs. You think their sale are going to skyrocket?

ALGER: Well, Amazon's going for it. I mean, it's got its pedal right on the firewall, and it's going to spend until everyone else drops out of the business; that's the objective. It could grow more slowly and make more money, but they're not doing that. And I think it's good strategy.

BAY: David Alger, Alger Funds, thanks for joining us tonight.

ALGER: Thank you.

VARNEY: Coming up: one for the record books, a company with a name taken from Hawaii soars on its market debut.

BAY: Akamai that would be.

And investors are not the only ones calling this IPO cool. We'll explain why when MONEYLINE returns.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: It helps speed up the Internet. And today, investors helped push Akamai Technology on the fast track to IPO history. The stock soared on its market debut, up more than 458 percent, making it the fourth best opening ever for an IPO. So what makes this company so special? Well, the name "Akamai" is a Hawaiian word for "cool," and as Bruce Francis reports, its ties to the Internet don't hurt either.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The need for speed catapulted Akamai in its first day of trading. The shares were offered at $26 apiece, and instantly soared to $110 at the open. By the end of the day, Akamai had an instant market value of over $13 billion -- not bad for a company that lost $28 million last year.

And what do they do? Akamai develops software that helps the Web run faster. Leading Web content firms like Yahoo! use Akamai Technology to speed delivery of information. Web traffic isn't steady, and when the clicks come fast and furious, it can take seven seconds or more to download a page of information -- an eternity in Internet time. Akamai says that its products can cut the Worldwide wait down to less than half a second most of the time. Akamai pulls this off with a combination of software and a network of servers scattered around the Web.

SUJATA RAMNARAYAN, INDUSTRY ANALYST, DATAQUEST: It's going to come from the server that's closest to you on the network, so that it bypasses a lot of the congestion on the Internet -- the congestion on the network, and you get your content much faster.

FRANCIS: Akamai has plenty of competition, including Alteon Web Systems, F5 Networks and Sandpiper Networks. But with the explosion of Web content, analysts say there is plenty of business now to go around.

RAMNARAYAN: As we all know, the number of Web sites is increasing every day. There's more and more content going on the Web as well. So -- and there's also more multimedia which is coming up on the Web.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: Well, file this IPO under "revenge of the nerds." Akamai's co-founder, MIT Professor F. Thomson Leighton, bought more than 11 million shares of Akamai for around $63,000. Tonight, his stake is worth more than $1.6 billion.

Aloha to that, Willow.

BAY: That would be sweet revenge, Bruce, very sweet. Thank you.

Bruce Francis reporting.

BAY: Coming up on MONEYLINE: the first blue chip Baby Bell.

VARNEY: And "The Bottom Line" on SBC Communications, about to join a very exclusive club. Our regular Friday special report is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Wall Street will begin the month of November with a brand new look for the world's most widely watched index. Starting Monday, IntelMicrosoft, Home Depot and SBC Communications are in. Sears, Union Carbide, Chevron and Goodyear are out.

MONEYLINE caught up with a co-founder of one of the new blue chips, who downplayed the honor. But of course he can afford to be blase.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL GATES, CHAIRMAN & CEO, MICROSOFT: I wouldn't say it's a big deal. It's not something I was thinking about. I don't think it affects the stock or the products or any of those things.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAY: "The Bottom Line" tonight look at one of Microsoft's Dow colleagues: SBC Communications. The Texas-based telecom is the nation's biggest Baby Bell, and it's about to become the first ever to join the venerable Dow 30.

Peter Viles has more on our regular Friday feature, inside one company on the move.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): 1984: The Reagan campaign called it "morning in America." It was the dawn also of a new age in the phone business. A landmark decision broke AT&T into seven Baby Bells. Fifteen years later, one of them has blossomed into a blue-chip stock. And it is not the Bell from New York, the nation's business capital, and not the Bell from Washington. It is the one from Texas, once known as Southwest Bell, now SBC Communications, built into a blue chip by a former engineer named Ed Whitacre.

DAVID OTTO, EDWARD JONES: SBC didn't have the best territory. They were spun off from AT&T in 1984 in the middle of one of the worst oil times in recent memory. And Oklahoma and Texas were shrinking; they weren't growing. Ed Whitacre came in the late '80s, early '90s, and really turned the ship around. He said -- he told investors what they were going to do, and then he went and did it.

VILES: What Whitacre did was put back together part of the national network the courts had broken up, merging with Pacific Telesis and then Ameritech.

OTTO: SBC broke the mold. They were the first one out of the box to buy a former Bell company, so a peer or a sister, if you will, in the Baby Bell divestiture when they went out to California and acquired Pacific Telesis a few years ago.

VILES: The resulting company owns 60 million local access lines. Only the planned combination of Bell Atlantic and GTE would have more. Whitacre has also built a wireless business with 10 million customers. Again, only Bell AtlanticGTE would have more.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The goal in telecommunications today is the one-stop shopping. It's one bill, one provider, one customer service agent. So your getting your traditional kitchen telephone service, you're getting your car phone, you're getting your cable TV, your Internet, and anything else that goes along with it, you're getting from one company, and SBC wants to be that one.

VILES: If the goal is to be all things to all customers. SBC is still hamstrung by regulators in long distance. It has less than one percent of that market, now dominated by AT&T and the MCI- Worldcom/Sprint combination. Still, it is one of the four clear leaders in telecommunications. Call it the $25 billion cash-flow club, according to PaineWebber estimates, for the year 2001.

But SBC's stock has had a choppy year, weighed down by conditions of the Ameritech merger and by plans for a huge spending spree. The company is putting $6 billion on the line to upgrade its local access lines for broadband, or high-speed, Internet delivery.

DON KIERNAN, CFO, SBC COMMUNICATIONS: It's an incredibly aggressive strategy. It brings the Internet to the home -- something that's been out there as a promise, but never fulfilled. It's going to create a lot of value for our shareowners, but it's a major change for us, and we're off and running; we're very excited about it.

VILES (on camera): SBC aims to win 50 percent of the market for high-speed Internet service, an aggressive goal that, and if they reach it, they give the Dow industrials not just a new telephone company, but a new Internet company.

Peter Viles, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: Still to come on MONEYLINE: on tonight's docket, the legal battle over a billion dollar estate. And guess who's coming to court?

VARNEY: But up next, "Ahead of the Curve," some of what you need to know tonight, before Monday's markets open.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Here's our check on what could move the markets next week: Microsoft, Intel, Home Depot and SBC Communications start trading as Dow components on Monday. Fed chief Alan Greenspan talks about the economy and mortgage rates to America's community bankers. That takes place on Tuesday. As far as economic reports, the all- important employment figures due out on Friday. Also expected, the latest numbers the manufacturing sector, personal income and spending, and chain store sales. On the earnings front: Cigna, Qualcomm and Oxford Health expected to report. And do watch Citrix Systems. The software company will replace Mobil in the S&P 500 index.

BAY: After a singular career as a poster girl for "Playboy" and Guess jeans, Anna Nicole Smith largely faded from her early 90's spotlight. Well, she's re-emerged tonight, involved in a bitter courtroom contest over the estate of her late husband. And if she wins, she instantly becomes one of the richest women in the world.

With the details, Casey Wian.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP, 1993)

ANNA NICOLE SMITH, MODEL: It's a big check.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASEY WIAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The $100,000 check Anna Nicole Smith received as "Playboy's" Playmate of the Year in 1993 may soon seem like not much more than a dollar bill in the ex- stripper's G-string. The former Guess model and actress is seeking at least $535 million from the estate of her late husband, Texas oil man J. Howard Marshall II. The two married in 1994, when she was 26 and he was 89.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SMITH: I want to tell my husband, J. Howard Marshall, that I love him very much, and I wish he was here, and I miss you and -- all my love to you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WIAN: Marshall died 14 months later, leaving a legacy of contested wills, family feuds and scattered assets courts in California and Texas are now trying to sort out.

SMITH: I can't comment about the case. I'm sorry.

WIAN: A lawyer for one of Marshall's sons called the claims by Smith, who in court is going by her real name, Vickie Lynn Marshall, a fantasy. Another of the billionaire's sons, already disinherited, is testifying in support of the widow Marshall.

Much of the billion dollar-plus estate consists of stock of Koch Industries, a Wichita, Kansas, oil company that's one of the nation's largest privately held firms.

PHILIP BOESCH, ANNA NICOLE SMITH ATTORNEY: The products and the extraordinary nature of Koch Industries, when someone says there's no money -- I guess a judge will have to decide.

WIAN: Smith, who has had drug and weight problems in the past, is now under a doctor's care for a herniated disk.

SMITH: Well, I'm very nervous.

WIAN: She lives with her 13-year-old son in a Los Angeles suburb, and wants to restart her career by opening her own film studio. But for now, she's bankrupt, and her legal battle is expected to last until January.

Casey Wian, CNN Financial News, Los Angeles.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: Well, that's MONEYLINE for this Friday. I'm Willow Bay.

VARNEY: Yes, it is. And I'm Stuart Varney. Thanks for joining us. Good night from New York.

"CROSSFIRE" is next.

urn:contentItem:5XPW-6941-JCMN-Y1TP-00000-00Tech Stocks Leading US Sectors By Wide Margin In 20192019-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:43ZLexisNexisTech Stocks Leading US Sectors By Wide Margin In 2019James Picerno

Dec 11, 2019( The Capital Spectator: http://www.capitalspectator.com/ Delivered by Newstex) As horse races go, this one isn't close. Shares of technology stocks are far ahead of the rest of the equity sector field this year, based on a set of exchange traded funds. Barring a dramatic reversal in the final weeks of December, it appears that tech will close out 2019 with an outsized gain.Technology Select Sector SPDR (XLK) closed on Tuesday (Dec.

10) with a red-hot 42.4% total return year to date. The performance leaves the remaining sector funds well behind XLK's blow-out performance in 2019. Based on recent trading, it appears that the fund still enjoys a solid upside bias.The second-best performer this year: Financial Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLF), up 29.2% so far in 2019. That's a strong gain, although it's no match for XLK's run.Learn To Use R For Portfolio Analysis Quantitative Investment Portfolio Analytics In R:An Introduction To R For Modeling Portfolio Risk and Return[1]By James PicernoMeanwhile, the spread between the strongest and weakest sector performances this year is conspicuously wide. More than 35 percentage points separates XLK's 2019 run over Energy Select Sector SPDR (XLE), which is up this year by a relatively muted 7.0%.Note, too, that the broad market is having a stellar year, in absolute and relative terms. SPDR S...00 (SPY) ended yesterday's trading session with a 27.2% total return - ahead of seven out of the 11 eleven sector funds in the chart above.Despite the strong rally in tech, there's growing concern that proposed regulations could hinder companies in this corner in the years ahead. Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren, for example, has outlined a plan[2] to break up the major tech firms. But for now, there's no sign that investors are worried, particularly for the mega-cap tech stocks. As a New York Times article earlier this week observed,[3] 'Big Tech Is Under Attack, and Investors Couldn't Care Less.' One of the reasons for the so-far unshakable optimism that graces the largest tech stocks, says Jeb Breece, principal at New York-based money manager Spears Abacus: 'They are more economically resilient. A dollar of tech earnings seems like more of a sure bet than a dollar of Midwestern steel earnings.'In fact, there's plenty of optimism to spread around these days. Profiling all the sector funds listed above through a momentum lens continues to reflect a bullish bias generally. The analysis is based on two sets of moving averages for the sector ETFs listed above. The first compares the 10-day moving average with its 100-day counterpart — a proxy for short-term trending behavior (red line in chart below). A second set of moving averages (50 and 200 days) represents an intermediate measure of the trend (blue line). Through yesterday's close, the two indicators continue to reflect a heavy dose of positive momentum overall.Is Recession Risk Rising? Monitor the outlook with a subscription to:The US Business Cycle Risk Report[4] [ 1]: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1987583515/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8...p=1789...ative=9325...ativeASIN=1987583515...kCode=as2...=bookscs-20...kId=020f71fb53a3e09903f46845853c189b [ 2]:   https://www.newyorker.com/business/currency/how-elizabeth-warren-came-up-with-a-plan-to-break-up-big-tech [ 3]:   https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/10/business/tech-stocks-apple-amazon-microsoft-google.html [ 4]:   http://www.capitalspectator.com/premium-research/

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S0C-7RN1-DY37-F2NW-00000-00Tech stocks losing some of their bite2018-03-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:43ZLexisNexisBUSINESSCPg. 2Tech stocks losing some of their biteJames F. Peltz

Investors expect big tech stocks such as Facebook to dominate their various spheres and continue big growth in the years to come.MANJUNATH KIRAN AFP/Getty Images

It has become a lot less easy to make money in tech stocks.

A confluence of negative news has rocked the shares of the nation's leading technology companies in recent days, though many of them bounced back Thursday. Developments at companies such as Amazon and Tesla have prompted investors to take a hard, fresh look at the firms' growth prospects and the stocks' lofty prices.

Facebook was hit with a data-privacy scandal. Amazon.com Inc.came under attack again by President Donald Trump over its sales taxes and U.S. Postal Service contract. Concern mounted about Tesla Inc.'s cash needs. The self-driving vehicle industry was roiled by a pedestrian fatality in Arizona caused by an autonomous Uber car.

Because the tech giants' stocks - and the stocks' enormous price gains in the last two years - have attracted an increasingly larger following, their abrupt declines helped bring down the overall stock market in March.

For instance, the NYSE FANG+ index plunged nearly 8 percent this week before finishing nearly unchanged Thursday. The index tracks the so-called FANG stocks - Facebook, Amazon, Netflix Inc.and Google parent Alphabet Inc. - and six others, including Tesla and Twitter Inc.

The broader, tech-heavy Nasdaq composite index, which soared 28 percent last year and gained an additional 5.4 percent in the first two months of this year, fell 2.9 percent in March, its worst monthly showing since January 2016.

"The gains were easy the last few years" with the big tech shares, said Jason Ware, chief investment officer at Albion Financial Group. "Investors haven't been challenged much with these stocks. Now, there's been news that questions their assumptions.

"Investors are now saying, 'Maybe the stock isn't worth as much as we thought,'" he said.

But as Wall Street heads into a three-day break - the market is closed today for Good Friday - the question is whether investors used the bad news simply to take some of their big profits or whether the developments point to trends that could curb the companies' longer-term business prospects, thus making current stock prices overvalued.

Consider: Even after tech's dreary week, Amazon is still up 66 percent over the last 12 months, compared with a 12 percent gain in the benchmark Standard & Poor's 500 index. Netflixhas doubled in price and Twitter has surged 93 percent in the period.

The gains mainly reflect investors' expectations that the firms enjoy dominance in their various spheres and will continue their heady growth in the years to come.

With gains like those, the negative news gave many investors an apt reason to cash out. And some of those investors were momentum players with little interest in the companies' long-term outlooks, Ware said.

"These folks are not fundamentally rooted in their analysis," Ware said. "They're just renting the stock when there's momentum. And when that momentum starts to turn, these folks will flee and take their profits."

For those investors looking at the tech giants for the long term, "one of the questions we're getting is whether the recent declines in these stocks (are) indicative of something more sinister in the market," said Adam Phillips, director of portfolio strategy at EP Wealth Advisors in Torrance.

"We don't subscribe to that" thinking and, in fact, see the stocks' recent pullback as "making them more attractive," Phillips said.

One example for Phillips is Amazon. Many traders seemed to agree Thursday, as Amazon recovered from early losses - and a 4.4 percent drop the prior day - and finished with a gain of 1 percent.

Facebook jumped 4.4 percent on Thursday but was still down 17 percent from Feb. 1. Netflixand Alphabet both rose 3 percent. Apple Inc., which is one of the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average, rose nearly 1 percent.

"A lot of [the selling] was profit-taking but also an acknowledgment that these stocks, which have trended higher for quite some time, have come under a different scrutiny and are getting the wrong kind of attention," Phillips said.

Facebook provides a good example of the challenge longer-term investors now face.

Owing to the scandal involving Cambridge Analytica, which gathered data from about 50 million Facebook users without their permission, Facebook is being investigated by the Federal Trade Commission and could be the focus of regulatory reform by Congress.

One argument for investors is that "the Cambridge fiasco represents a seminal negative moment that will change the future business model and growth trajectory of Facebook," Daniel Ives, head of technology research at GBH Insights, said in a recent note to clients.

But Ives said "we ultimately believe Facebook will emerge from this crisis with minimal regulatory changes and limited financial damage to its user base and advertising kingdom," even if this represents "the darkest chapter for Facebook and [CEO Mark] Zuckerberg in its 14-year history."

Peltz writes for the California News Group, publisher of the Union-Tribune and Los Angeles Times.

urn:contentItem:6014-1ND1-F03R-N4VX-00000-00Tech Stocks Offer A Rare Bright Spot For 2020 Sector Returns2020-05-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:43ZLexisNexisTech Stocks Offer A Rare Bright Spot For 2020 Sector ReturnsJames Picerno

May 29, 2020( The Capital Spectator: http://www.capitalspectator.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The US stock market's volatile run in 2020 has left most corners of the equity market with deep losses or mostly flat results this year — with one glaring exception: technology. Year to date, the tech sector is enjoying a solid gain - a conspicuous outlier so far in 2020, based on a set of exchange traded funds.Technology Select Sector SPDR (XLK) is up 6.1% so far this year (through May 28). Although the fund was clobbered with everything else during the dramatic selling wave in March, the fund has rebounded sharply and has recovered nearly all its previous loss.

http://www.capitalspectator.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/xlk.29may2020.png Even health care, presumably the darling sector in a health care crisis, can't compete on a year-to-date basis. Although Health Care Select Sector SPDR (XLV) has also mounted a robust recovery in recent weeks, at the moment the fund's year-to-date performance is virtually flat with a fractional 0.4% gain.Learn To Use R For Portfolio Analysis Quantitative Investment Portfolio Analytics In R:An Introduction To R For Modeling Portfolio Risk and Return[1]By James PicernoIn fact, most of the US equity market's sectors remain underwater this year, with financials and energy leading the red-ink brigade. Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE) is the worst performer in 2020. Although the fund has bounced modestly since late-March, it remains deep in the hole with a 33.6% decline this year. Stocks generally continue to suffer on a year-to-date basis. The market benchmark remains down 5.3% through yesterday's closed, based on SPDR S&P 500 (SPY).   http://www.capitalspectator.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/sectors.etfs_.ytd_.barplot.2020-05-29-1.png A key driver of tech's rally is linked to expectations of rising fortunes for the largest companies in the sector. In a sign of the times, the leading names in this corner are reportedly ramping up searches to exploit opportunities. The FT notes[2] that the largest tech firms are on a 'pandemic mergers-and-acquisitions spree,' courtesy of high cash balances in the hundreds of billions of dollars. 'This crisis threatens to further entrench the power of Big Tech,' notes[3] Sandeep Vaheesan, legal director at the Open Markets Institute, a think-tank. 'These companies are already extraordinarily powerful, but they're well positioned to emerge as the biggest winners of COVID-19 unless some legislative action is taken.' The question is whether there's a political backlash is brewing? The topic appears to be heating up after President Donald Trump yesterday signed an executive order[4] that reduces legal protections for social media companies. It's unclear what awaits the tech sector from a regulatory perspective. But for traders looking for opportunities to take sector profits, the tech sector's gains this year are a rare bird.How is recession risk evolving? Monitor the outlook with a subscription to:The US Business Cycle Risk Report[5] [ 1]:   https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1987583515/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=1987583515&linkCode=as2&tag=bookscs-20&linkId=020f71fb53a3e09903f46845853c189b [ 2]:   https://www.ft.com/content/04a62a26-42aa-4ad9-839e-05d762466fbe [ 3]:   https://business.financialpost.com/technology/with-a-us560-billion-war-chest-big-tech-goes-on-pandemic-ma-spree-despite-political-backlash [ 4]:   https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/28/trump-targets-social-media-with-executive-order-after-twitter-fact-checks-him.html [ 5]:   http://www.capitalspectator.com/premium-research/

urn:contentItem:5S05-4471-JBKR-93MX-00000-00Tech stocks pressured, energy weighs down TSX2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:43ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B2Tech stocks pressured, energy weighs down TSX

Canada's main stock index closed down Wednesday as commodity prices slipped, while increased scrutiny on U.S. technology stocks put downward pressure on U.S. markets.

The day's market drop follow a trend of down days recently as concerns over trade wars and regulatory investigations into premier tech stocks have rumbled markets, said Norman Levine, managing Director of Portfolio Management Corp. in Toronto.

"It's generally got a negative tone to it, and it's continuing to be led by the high-flying tech stocks for the most part."

The S&;P/TSX composite index closed down 46.24 points at 15,169.94, driven by base metals and materials as worries about Chinese growth and demand increase, said Levine. "Metal stocks are more worried about growth in China and they need that for higher metal prices, and metal prices aren't doing a whole lot right now, and gold is weak today as well."

In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average closed down 9.29 points at 23,848.42. The S&;P 500 index closed down 7.62 points at 2,605.00 and the Nasdaq composite index was down 59.58 points to 6,949.23.

The declines included losses from major U.S. tech stocks, with Amazon falling on reports U.S. President Donald Trump is looking to go after the company and Tesla declining on a downgraded credit rating and more concerns over the self-driving vehicles, following recent declines at Facebook and Twitter.

Shares of Amazon plunged after a report that Trump is "obsessed" with the e-commerce giant and wants to "go after" the company.

News site Axios reported that Trump brings up Amazon when discussing tax policy and antitrust cases. The president reportedly hears from real estate friends that the Seattle-based online giant is destroying shopping malls, mom-and-pop stores and brick-and-mortar retailers - and he believes them.

According to an unidentified source that spoke to Trump, the president has "wondered aloud if there may be any way to go after Amazon with antitrust or competition law," Axios reported.

Amazon stock was down 6.4 percent Wednesday morning.

Trump has repeatedly posted on Twitter about Amazon over the past year. In August, he wrote that the company was "doing great damage to tax paying retailers. Towns, cities and states throughout the U.S. are being hurt - many jobs being lost!" Trump's ire has also extended to the

Washington Post, which is owned by Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos. The president has frequently referred to the Post as the "Amazon Washington Post." "The big story here is the big tech stocks trading at multiples that make no sense, but they were going up purely on momentum, the wind is coming out of the sail here, and they're looking vulnerable and bringing down the rest of the market with them," said Levine.

The decline in stocks was felt in Canada as well, where BlackBerry Ltd. beat analyst expectations with $233 million US of revenue for the last quarter, but slipped 1.38 per cent to $15.76 on the TSX.

The stock losses from particular issues at larger technology companies are, however, likely distorting the view of the overall health of market because they have so much sway over some of the indexes, said Levine. "Indexes are going to show, especially in the U.S., more negative than what's going on with the average stock."

The Canadian dollar closed at 77.51, down 0.2 of a US cent.

The May crude contract ended down 87 cents at US$64.38 per barrel and the May natural gas contract was down two cents at US$2.69 per mmBTU. The June gold contract closed down US$17.90 to US$1,330.00 an ounce and the May copper contract was even at US$3 a pound. - With files from the Los Angeles Times

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5MN5-B331-DY60-K3CH-00000-00Tech stocks soar as growth trumps Trump fears2017-01-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:43ZLexisNexisINVESTINGTech stocks soar as growth trumps Trump fearsPaul R. La Monica

So much for fears of Donald Trump's presidency hurting tech stocks.

While the Dow continues its flirtation with 20,000 (will it EVER get there?) the Nasdaq keeps hitting new record highs. And it's being led by four prominent tech companies that collectively are known by the acronym of FANG.

Facebook. Amazon. Netflix. Google-- whose parent company is now technically Alphabet, but its ticker symbol still starts with a G.

Facebook is the hottest of these Fab Four stocks. Shares of the social network are already up nearly 12% in just the first two weeks of the year. Amazon and Netflix are each up more than 8%. Google's shares have gained 5%.

What makes Facebook's performance even more astonishing is that it has come despite criticism about fake news proliferating on Facebook, concerns about some of its metrics being wrong and speculation that CEO Mark Zuckerberg may seek public office.

But investors are looking past that and focusing on the fact that Facebook is expected to keep posting impressive levels of growth.

Analysts are predicting that Facebook will report a year-over-year revenue increase of 45% for the fourth quarter and 65% surge in earnings per share. Facebook will report its results on February 1.

Wall Street is bullish about the earnings prospects for the other FANG stocks too. Netflix, which will kick off tech earnings season when it reports its results Wednesday, is expected to post sales and earnings increases of more than 30% from a year ago.

Analysts are forecasting a 25% jump in sales for Amazon and more than 35% increase in profits. And Googleis expected to report earnings growth of 11% and a revenue increase of nearly 20%.

It seems that these strong fundamentals are trumping Trump fears. Tech investors were worried in the immediate aftermath of Trump's win over Hillary Clinton for several reasons.

Concerns about a crackdown on immigration, most notably on H1-B visas that allow many foreign workers to come to Silicon Valley, hurt the stocks of big tech companies.

Trump's protectionist rhetoric wasn't helping either since most large tech companies do big business overseas.

But sentiment has shifted in the past few weeks. Investors are focusing more on some of the potential positives of a Trump administration.

The meeting that Trump held with leaders of several big tech companies in New York last month seemed to help allay some of the concerns investors had about Trump.

Investors also seem to recognize that corporate tax reform, particularly changes that could allow companies to bring back cash being held overseas at lower rates, could be good for the tech sector.

Googlesaid in its most recent earnings report in October that it had $50 billion in cash and investments, 60% of its overall cash hoard, outside of the U.S. Apple and Microsoft hold an even bigger percentage of their cash overseas.

Eric Ervin, CEO of Reality Shares, an investment firm that runs several ETFs focused on dividends, said Monday that assuming Trump follows through on his tax reform promise, more tech companies may consider paying dividends.

Ervin highlighted Google, Amazon and Facebook as three that have enough cash to easily afford a dividend.

"It's reasonable to assume most of those companies will want to put that cash to work," he said.

Tech stocks are also rallying on the hopes of broader economic stimulus from Trump and the Republican Congress.

It stands to reason that if $1 trillion is spent on the nation's roads, bridges and other physical infrastructure, that could boost overall economic growth. That would be good for tech companies too, especially if stimulus lifts consumer spending.

But are investors too optimistic?

Terri Spath, chief investment officer of Sierra Investment Management, wrote in a recent report to clients that she's worried that the market rally is about to stall.

"Stimulative policy should turbocharge growth and boost corporate profits, but stocks are ahead of themselves," she wrote.

"The anticipation of changes in tax and regulatory policy are ahead of the reality right now. We like the improved optimism in corporations and consumers," she added. "We are just saying, proceed with caution. The sugar high is wearing off."

urn:contentItem:5MN5-B2T1-JBSS-S0F9-00000-00Tech stocks soar as growth trumps Trump fears2017-01-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:43ZLexisNexisTech stocks soar as growth trumps Trump fearsBy Paul R. La MonicaNEW YORK (CNNMoney)

NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- So much for fears of Donald Trump's presidency hurting tech stocks.

While the Dow continues its flirtation with 20,000 (will it EVER get there?) the Nasdaq keeps hitting new record highs. And it's being led by four prominent tech companies that collectively are known by the acronym of FANG.

Facebook. Amazon. Netflix. Google-- whose parent company is now technically Alphabet, but its ticker symbol still starts with a G.

Facebookis the hottest of these Fab Four stocks. Shares of the social network are already up nearly 12% in just the first two weeks of the year. Amazon and Netflix are each up more than 8%. Google's shares have gained 5%.

What makes Facebook's performance even more astonishing is that it has come despite criticism about fake news proliferating on Facebook, concerns about some of its metrics being wrong and speculation that CEO Mark Zuckerberg may seek public office.

But investors are looking past that and focusing on the fact that Facebookis expected to keep posting impressive levels of growth.

Analysts are predicting that Facebookwill report a year-over-year revenue increase of 45% for the fourth quarter and 65% surge in earnings per share. Facebookwill report its results on February 1.

Wall Street is bullish about the earnings prospects for the other FANG stocks too. Netflix, which will kick off tech earnings season when it reports its results Wednesday, is expected to post sales and earnings increases of more than 30% from a year ago.

Analysts are forecasting a 25% jump in sales for Amazon and more than 35% increase in profits. And Googleis expected to report earnings growth of 11% and a revenue increase of nearly 20%.

It seems that these strong fundamentals are trumping Trump fears. Tech investors were worried in the immediate aftermath of Trump's win over Hillary Clinton for several reasons.

Concerns about a crackdown on immigration, most notably on H1-B visas that allow many foreign workers to come to Silicon Valley, hurt the stocks of big tech companies.

Trump's protectionist rhetoric wasn't helping either since most large tech companies do big business overseas.

But sentiment has shifted in the past few weeks. Investors are focusing more on some of the potential positives of a Trump administration.

The meeting that Trump held with leaders of several big tech companies in New York last month seemed to help allay some of the concerns investors had about Trump.

Investors also seem to recognize that corporate tax reform, particularly changes that could allow companies to bring back cash being held overseas at lower rates, could be good for the tech sector.

Googlesaid in its most recent earnings report in October that it had $50 billion in cash and investments, 60% of its overall cash hoard, outside of the U.S. Apple and Microsoft hold an even bigger percentage of their cash overseas.

Eric Ervin, CEO of Reality Shares, an investment firm that runs several ETFs focused on dividends, said Monday that assuming Trump follows through on his tax reform promise, more tech companies may consider paying dividends.

Ervin highlighted Google, Amazon and Facebookas three that have enough cash to easily afford a dividend.

"It's reasonable to assume most of those companies will want to put that cash to work," he said.

Tech stocks are also rallying on the hopes of broader economic stimulus from Trump and the Republican Congress.

It stands to reason that if $1 trillion is spent on the nation's roads, bridges and other physical infrastructure, that could boost overall economic growth. That would be good for tech companies too, especially if stimulus lifts consumer spending.

But are investors too optimistic?

Terri Spath, chief investment officer of Sierra Investment Management, wrote in a recent report to clients that she's worried that the market rally is about to stall.

"Stimulative policy should turbocharge growth and boost corporate profits, but stocks are ahead of themselves," she wrote.

"The anticipation of changes in tax and regulatory policy are ahead of the reality right now. We like the improved optimism in corporations and consumers," she added. "Proceed with caution. The sugar high is wearing off."

urn:contentItem:5BTR-5JW1-JBPX-W011-00000-00Tech stocks tank but finish off their lows2014-03-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:43ZLexisNexisINVESTINGTech stocks tank but finish off their lowsJesse Solomon

It was a tough start to the week for technology stocks.

The Nasdaq, which has been the best performing market index of the year, fell more than 1% Monday. So did CNNMoney's Tech 30 index. The Dow and S&P 500 also ended lower, but not nearly as much.

Despite the sell-off, stocks regained some lost ground late in the trading session. The Nasdaq was down 2% earlier in the day.

Netflix was under the most pressure. The stock fell almost 7% and was the biggest loser in the Tech 30.

It appears that Netflix investors are worried about the possibility of competition from Apple after the Wall Street Journal reported that the company is exploring a partnership with Comcast for an Apple-branded TV service. Shares of Apple were actually one of the few big tech stocks moving higher.

"$AAPL the one day apple goes up the nasdaq tanks...no luck with this stock," said BarryBye on StockTwits.

But Netflix wasn't the only momentum tech taking a beating. Some other well-known Internet stocks, including Yahoo!, Linkedin, Twitter, Priceline and Facebook, also suffered.

StockTwits trader StrayTrader wasn't surprised by the tech sector's decline.

"$LNKD $NFLX never had any rational basis for valuations at their peak levels ... both could plunge from here and still be overvalued," he said.

StockTwits user OptionsHero echoed that sentiment.

"The old stairs up, elevator down saying is in full effect. $PCLN, $NFLX," he said.

Biotech stocks, which had been on a tear this year, also pulled back. The iShares NasdaqBiotechnology ETF dropped almost 3%. The sector is considered speculative because investors are in many cases betting on drugs that have yet to be approved. The leaders in the industry, while profitable, also tend to trade at very high valuations.

Shares of Nu Skin surged over 18% after the company said it was fined around $700,000 for its business practices in China. The beauty products marketer had previously disclosed that it was being investigated by Chinese regulators, but the relatively small penalty seems to be a relief to investors who had feared a more major regulatory blow.

"$NUS Wow you gotta be kidding me ... fine is like glass of water in an ocean for NUS, this stock has buy written all over it! Very bullish," said Championinvestor.

Herbalife, the nutritional supplements distributor that uses a similar multi-level marketing sales model as Nu Skin, also rallied on the news. Herbalife revealed earlier this month that it is being probed by the Federal Trade Commission.

The company has been in the crosshairs of hedge fund manager Bill Ackman, who has publicly called it a pyramid scheme and unveiled a large bet that its stock price would fall. He also recently disclosed what he says are more shady tactics by the company in China.

Lions Gate shares rose almost 4% after the studio's film "Divergent" had a strong opening at the box office. Many analysts expected a weaker showing for the movie.

StockTwits trader Chase03670 felt that the film could have staying power.

"Friendly reminder that HS spring breaks begin this week and extend into April. A+ CinemaScore among under 18 yr olds bodes well. $LGF," he noted.

Investors were also gearing up for some high profile initial public offerings in the days ahead.

King Digital Entertainment, the company behind the popular Candy Crush Saga online game is one of 14 companies currently scheduled to go public this week.

The IPO mania is part of a global trend, as more and more companies seek to go public in order to take advantage of increased demand for stocks.

European stock markets closed mostly lower as the Russian takeover of Ukraine's Crimean peninsula continues to dominate sentiment.

Asian markets ended with some significant gains though, despite HSBC data that showed Chinese manufacturing activity fell to an eight-month low in March. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong shot up by 1.9% and the Shanghai Composite rose by 0.9%.
